titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ralph Waldo Emerson Collection
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:17

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Emerson collection contains correspondence, manuscripts, photographs, and prints documenting the life and work of Ralph Waldo Emerson.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired by gift and purchase from various sources.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Ralph Waldo Emerson Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ralph Waldo Emerson Collection. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ralph Waldo Emerson Collection contains correspondence, manuscripts, photographs, and artwork documenting the life and work of Ralph Waldo Emerson.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Owen Franklin Aldis Gift, 1837-1877. II. Kenneth W. Cameron Gifts, 1793-1871. III. Julia Millhiser Gimbel Gift, 1872. IV. Eliza Brush Pirsson Gift, 1848-1932. V. Material from Other Sources, 1832-1937.

controlaccess.subject: American literature -- 19th century
Authors, American -- 19th century -- Archives
controlaccess.persname: Botta, Anne C. Lynch (Anne Charlotte Lynch), 1815-1891
controlaccess.corpname: Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence consists of letters from Emerson to others, including author and clergyman William Rounseville Alger, Anne C. Botta, publisher James Thomas Fields, and William James Linton. There are three autograph manuscript leaves of the manuscript Parnassus.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into two subseries: Correspondence and Writings.

did.unittitle: Blake, H. G. O. (Harrison Gray Otis)
Botta, Anne C. Lynch (Anne Charlotte Lynch )

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence contains several outgoing letters, including three letters to Irish poet William Allingham, and one third party letter from Emerson's father William to his sister Rebecca. Writings contains autograph manuscript notes for a lecture on Emerson by Henry Septimus Sutton.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into two subseries: Correspondence and Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Gimbel gift contains a single letter from Emerson to Edward Cornelius Towne and autograph manuscripts of five poems.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is organized into two subseries: Correspondence and Writings.

did.unittitle: "Each and All, " poem, autograph manuscript, corrected and bound

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes reproduction of engraving by Timothy Cole

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Pirsson gift includes third-party correspondence relating to Emerson and Thomas Carlyle, drafts of a manuscript by Pirsson, and a daguerreotype of Emerson. There are letters between Eliza Brush Pirsson, Louis Valentine Pirsson, and Wilbur L. Cross, and one letter from Carlyle to Joseph Neuberg.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV is organized into two subseries: Third-party Correspondence and Other Material.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes copies of undated letter from Edward Waldo Emerson to Wilbur L. Cross in Pirsson's hand

did.unittitle: To and from Eliza Brush Pirsson

odd.head: General
odd.p: Typescript copies, one with undated note from Townsend Scudder to an unidentified recipient.

did.unittitle: "A New Portrait of Emerson" by Eliza Brush Pirsson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes letters from Emerson to Elliot C. Cowdin and Alexander Milton Ross. There are third-party letters from Emerson's daughter, Ellen Tucker Emerson, and from Peter Henry Emerson. Other letters to Charles Ganz from the British Journal of Photography and the Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain concern the death of British photographer Peter Henry Emerson, a distant relative. Artwork contains photographs of Emerson and his home in Concord, Massachusetts, and representations of Emerson in engravings, a lithograph, and a photogravure.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series V is organized into three subseries: Correspondence, Artwork, and Other Material.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Acquired by gift or purchase from various sources. Sources are indicated on individual folders.

did.unittitle: Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain
Allingham, William to William Hepworth Dixon
Emerson, Ellen Tucker to John Page Hopps
Emerson, Ellen Tucker to Hannah Parsons

did.physloc: Also stored in: Oversize, Box 2, folder 65

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes photographs by the Curtiss Studio and Warren; and photograph of Emerson's home in Concord, Massachusetts.

did.unittitle: Envelope addressed to James Edward Lewis in Emerson's hand
